repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Fixes to:
* some string methods
* iter next (due to type slots)
* module cleanup (temporary fix because access to module state is unreliable)

comment_data.body: I think this change won't be needed after https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/5323. That's the "right" fix, and this is just a fairly quick temporary measure.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3414,6 +3414,15 @@ def generate_module_cleanup_func(self, env, code):
                    Naming.cleanup_cname)
         code.enter_cfunc_scope(env)
 
+        # TODO - this should go away when module-state has been refactored more and
+        # we are able to access the module state through "self". Currently the
+        # `#define` for each entry forces us to access it through PyState_FindModule
+        # which is sometime unreliable during destruction
+        # (e.g. during interpreter shutdown).
+        # In that case the safest thing is to give up.
+        code.putln(f"if (!PyState_FindModule(&{Naming.pymoduledef_cname}))")
+        code.putln("return;")

comment_data.body: I'm less convinced it'll be completely unneeded after a bit more thought (since destructors can call into arbitrary code outside the module's cleanup function). Further refactors to reduce the dependence of `PyState_FindModule` will help though. And we might be able to split it into cached constants (safe) and everything else (unsafe).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3414,6 +3414,15 @@ def generate_module_cleanup_func(self, env, code):
                    Naming.cleanup_cname)
         code.enter_cfunc_scope(env)
 
+        # TODO - this should go away when module-state has been refactored more and
+        # we are able to access the module state through "self". Currently the
+        # `#define` for each entry forces us to access it through PyState_FindModule
+        # which is sometime unreliable during destruction
+        # (e.g. during interpreter shutdown).
+        # In that case the safest thing is to give up.
+        code.putln(f"if (!PyState_FindModule(&{Naming.pymoduledef_cname}))")
+        code.putln("return;")

comment_data.body:
Note that the `return` is not indented and just makes the generated code look misleading.
```suggestion
        code.putln(f"if (!PyState_FindModule(&{Naming.pymoduledef_cname})) return;")
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3414,6 +3414,15 @@ def generate_module_cleanup_func(self, env, code):
                    Naming.cleanup_cname)
         code.enter_cfunc_scope(env)
 
+        # TODO - this should go away when module-state has been refactored more and
+        # we are able to access the module state through "self". Currently the
+        # `#define` for each entry forces us to access it through PyState_FindModule
+        # which is sometime unreliable during destruction
+        # (e.g. during interpreter shutdown).
+        # In that case the safest thing is to give up.
+        code.putln(f"if (!PyState_FindModule(&{Naming.pymoduledef_cname}))")
+        code.putln("return;")

comment_data.body: `next` is an owned reference that needs decrefing.

So, maybe name it `__Pyx_PyType_TryGetSlot()` to make sure that it's not guaranteed to work in all cases/environments? "StaticSafe" isn't a very clear name for me. It suggests something like "safe to use on static types" where I usually don't know or don't want to care whether what I have in my hands might be statically defined or not. It's unclear why it wants me to care.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -861,11 +861,19 @@ static CYTHON_INLINE void *__Pyx_PyModule_GetState(PyObject *op)
 }
 #endif
 
+// The "static safe" variants may return NULL on static types with the Limited API on earlier versions
+// so should be used for optimization rather than where a result is required.

comment_data.body:
The cast seems wrong in the `-1` case. The function returns an `int`.
```suggestion
            return likely(asString) ? (unsigned char) asString[i] : -1;
```

Given that this copying is a somewhat heavy operation just to get a buffer, it might be worth adding another special case for bytearray here. Everything else seems sufficiently less common to just do a copy.
This looks like it would need error handling.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3444,6 +3444,15 @@ def generate_module_cleanup_func(self, env, code):
                    Naming.cleanup_cname)
         code.enter_cfunc_scope(env)
 
+        # TODO - this should go away when module-state has been refactored more and
+        # we are able to access the module state through "self". Currently the
+        # `#define` for each entry forces us to access it through PyState_FindModule
+        # which is sometime unreliable during destruction
+        # (e.g. during interpreter shutdown).
+        # In that case the safest thing is to give up.
+        code.putln(f"if (!PyState_FindModule(&{Naming.pymoduledef_cname}))")
+        code.putln("return;")

commit.message:
string/iter/shutdown limited API fixes

Fixes to:
* some string methods
* iter next (due to type slots)
* module cleanup (temporary fix because access to module state
  is unreliable)
